0.author: too_late_to_abort
0.body:
I understand that. In order to make them relative you make it a fraction expressed in 1 in X. This way it gives you a % of people who die doing any activity regardless of the total amount of people doing that activity.

If 100,000 people a year skydive and 1000 of them die you boil it down to 1 in 100 or 1%

You're saying you couldn't compare this statistic to something like driving since *way* more people drive than skydive. The way you compare them is figuring out how many people die per 100 drivers. Probably something a lot lower like 0.01 per 100.

The only thing that the total number of people doing the activity influences is the accuracy of that %. The more people you have doing it the more accurate it is but you work with what you have.

Edit; grammar

19.author: Industrial_Tech
19.body: Okay, I'll take back the Pol Pot comment. So in summary you're saying education has diminishing returns since median purchasing power has remained the same since the 1970s.  This has two issues:  Education, as indicated by reading proficiency rates, hasn't actually improved since the 1970s [source](https://www.winginstitute.org/have-reading-scores-improved865).  In other words the poor have the same issue with aquiring adequate education as they always have.  The other issue is, we're stretching what that purchasing power can tell us.  For example, comparing apples to apples, it wouldn't indicate 85% of Americans are carrying a device in their pocket with (literally) millions of times more computing power than the best computers ever built at the time.  In summary, the poor are just as poor since they're not able to participate in the economy any better than before, while the richer are continuing to reap the huge economic improvements from the investments made in STEM.

The US spends roughly $17k per student in public education (avg across all states).  The average private school tuition is only about $12k.

36.author: DuckDuckJeeper
36.body:
Slow down there Skippy….

Let’s pretend you get your wish and every single taxpayer is now chartered to pay for “Free to Student” education. 

Common sense says if you’re paying for something, you’re a fool not to benefit. If everyone goes, the cost increases but does the payout? If it doesn’t drive equity, returns and increased attendance, do we get to pay less until we’re right back to where we are today? (Hint hint)

Will a roofer suddenly make $120K a season with a mechanical engineering degree that isn’t necessary to lay tar paper and shingle a roof? Here’s the rub:

In the grand scheme of things, jobs that actually require secondary education are less than 30% of the total

The price of college has increased exponentially in the past 30 years

Yet the demand (and promised income) has been stagnant at best and has actually gone down for some professions

Not every citizen has the learning skills, proximity, resources or need for secondary education but every citizen must pay for it

Do you see the disconnect?

“Free college” certainly benefits the colleges just like free COVID shots benefits the Pfizer CEO far more than the researcher who developed it. (Katalin Karikó total net worth $5M compared to Pfizer CEO, Albert Bourla at $43.2M)

Does it sound right to legislate citizens MUST give their money to schools knowing we all can’t graduate and be CEO of Apple. Someone still has to drill the well, fix the car and cut lumber.

That said, I’m not against a path forward, I’m against a path to nowhere simply because people say it’s needed but can’t give a reasonable explanation as to why.

Now that the blame can’t go to FoxNews and MSNBC, how do you recommend how to proceed sensibly?

65.author: CopiumAddiction
65.body:
Ok fine, let's change the subject *completely* and talk about what you want to talk about. 

Biological sex is a bimodally distributed spectrum where most people fall under male or female sex based on a number of different sex-linked traits. Intersex people who are both male and female or neither male or female (depending on your perspective) exist. The biological sex of a person is generally determined by sex-linked chromosomes but people can be born with 3 X chromosomes or 2 Y chromosomes. The vast majority of people (trans people included) fall under the male or female sex.

On the other hand, gender is how someone's personal expression lines up with socially-crafted gender norms. In our society we apply arbitrary characteristics and preferences to particular genders and when people don't have see themselves as falling into those gendered norms, they sometimes choose to express themselves in ways that conform to different genders. So when you ask "what is a woman?" I can easily say that it's someone who conforms to traditionally female gender norms, regardless of their biological sex.

67.author: Educational-Fig-2330
67.body: Since you never served, you are understandably approaching this from a civilian's perspective. In the military it's _NOT_ all about intent and repeat mistakes. The idea that "you need 4 writeups to fire someone" is a uniquely corporate one. Intent and/or history is _sometimes_ (or _usually_, depending on command) taken into account depending on the seriousness of the infraction and upon the whim of the commanding officer or whoever is doling out the punishments. I don't know what the "by the book" prescription is for flight deck crew members who destroy plane engines (whether or not injured), but I can assure you there is one, and this guy dodged that bullet. At the discretion of the ship's captain it must have been decided that being sucked into an engine was punishment enough, but the captain would have been justified in discharging him. I served on submarines and on a submarine, there list of fuckups that _wont_ kill the entire crew and waste a billion dollar asset is much shorter than the list of fuckups which _will_. So I am not used to seeing things go unpunished. There have been a handful of submarine collisions in the past couple decades. If you're curious, Google them and read what happened to the CO, XO, Chief of the Boat, and everyone who was on watch in the control room when those collisions happened.

Thankfully I have no disability so never had to mess with the VA. I had surgery twice on active duty as well as seeking care for typical illnesses in military hospitals and the level of care I received was excellent. Not at all like the horror stories I've heard about the VA hospitals. Yet the government is "involved" in both. Why is one good while the other is abysmal? 

I think there are a few factors. 

1. The reason why I only (_somewhat_) agree with your sentiments about leniency with regards to intent and history of fuckups. Military hospitals are staffed and ran by Military personnel who play by military rules. VA hospitals and their employees are paid out of the bottomless pocket of uncle Sam, but are staffed by "federal employees" - technically not "civilians" but... yeah, civilians. Finances and level of care managed by people with an "8 strikes you're out" mentality. 

2. These "federal employees" are operating under a quasi-"corporate" mentality that is unburdened by any notion of "the customer is always right" or "customer satisfaction is our goal" or anything of the sort. They get paid the same whether their patients are pleased, healthy, dead, whatever. There is no supply and demand, no competition; nothing that governs the free market applies to them. They play by the same rules as the assholes behind the counter at the DMV. They have no incentive to be excellent. None of that free market incentive exists in the military either, hence why military spending (AKA wanton subsidizing of the military-industrial complex) accounts for so much of the national "budget," but excellence is demanded in the military and those demands are enforced with sufficient regularity that nobody has any illusion of having a "get out of jail free card" in their pocket, even for a first offense or an honest mistake.

3. There are throngs of able-bodied veterans making laughable claims which get approved because more dependents means more funding. Guy comes back from a 5 mile run through the mountains and gets in a car with "disabled veteran" plates; later at a bar he will brag to someone about how his 20% for sleep apnea, 10% for shingles, 40% for shin splints, 15% for generalized anxiety and 15% for vertigo add up to 100%. I can't tell you how many worthless fucks I know who do this. Freeloaders. Looters. And, also they veterans, so who can call them out? _ME_.

4. It is my understanding that a lot of VA care is farmed out to private entities with government contracts. This is the worst kind of crap. Worst of both/all worlds. These are civilian DMV assholes who get to name their own price. Like the fuckers who work for the Toll Road company or the electric utility company. They have you under their thumb, you are _forced_ to deal with them, they know that, and they act accordingly. They seem to actually take pleasure in treating people like shit. I can't _imagine_ seeking medical care from people like this. Disgusting. 

IMO, 100% free market industry or 100% government-ran is the way to go. Anything in the middle, any kind of combination or amalgamation of the two is an assured disaster. My personal preference for almost everything is 100% free market, but there are certain industries where the equations governing the free market are unbalanced by infinite demand, resulting in ballooning prices for diminishing returns (like Healthcare, insurance, etc.). Any attempt to control things to a reasonable level by imposing regulation on these industries just makes things worse. Every time. Every time the government gets involved, they screw things up. That (existing regulations) is part of the problems we have today but the root of it is the infinite demand. People's lives are literally at stake and they'll pay any amount the bank will lend them.

IMO the VA should be siezed by the military, flushed of shitbags, and ran the way the military runs things. The existing spending of the top brass should be audited, military spending cut by half (we could do that without losing a single iota of military readiness) and that money used to start a public Healthcare system patterned after the military's Healthcare system (_NOT_ patterned after the existing VA). 100% government-ran. No monkeys in the middle. Think of it like the public school system. No, It's not the best; you can get a better education for your kids by paying for private school, but it's there for everyone who needs it, and it's not some abortion of a private industry funded by infinite government funds.
